member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.BatteryHandler
member.summary: This class manages information and real-time status of the connected product's batteries.

member.name: P:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.BatteryHandler.ProductIndex
member.summary: The index of the product to which this component handler belongs. The default product index is 0.

member.name: P:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.BatteryHandler.ComponentIndex
member.summary: The index of the component. It is unique for a type of components inside a product. It is useful when a product has multiple handlers of the same kind. If the product only has one handler of this kind, the index is 0.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.BatteryHandler.Finalize
member.summary: The destructor. It should not be called explicitly.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.BatteryHandler.GetFullChargeCapacityAsync
member.summary: Gets the event to receive changes of the total amount of energy, in mAh (milliamp hours), stored in the battery when the battery is fully charged. The energy of the battery at full charge changes over time as the battery continues to get used. Over time, as the battery continues to be recharged, the value of fullChargeCapacity will decrease.

member.name: E:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.BatteryHandler.FullChargeCapacityChanged
member.summary: Subscribe the event to receive changes of the total amount of energy, in mAh (milliamp hours), stored in the battery when the battery is fully charged. The energy of the battery at full charge changes over time as the battery continues to get used. Over time, as the battery continues to be recharged, the value of fullChargeCapacity will decrease.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.BatteryHandler.GetChargeRemainingAsync
member.summary: Gets the remaining energy stored in the battery in mAh (milliamp hours).

member.name: E:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.BatteryHandler.ChargeRemainingChanged
member.summary: Subscribe the event to receive changes of the remaining energy stored in the battery in mAh (milliamp hours).

member.summary: Gets the percentage of battery energy left with range [0, 100].

member.name: E:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.BatteryHandler.ChargeRemainingInPercentChanged
member.summary: Subscribe the event to receive changes of the percentage of battery energy left with range [0, 100].

member.summary: Gets the real time current draw of the battery (mA). A negative value means the battery is being discharged, and a positive value means it is being charged.

member.summary: Sets the camera shutter speed. To see all available shutterSpeed value settings, see `CameraShutterSpeed`. The shutter speed should not be set slower than the video frame rate when the camera's mode is `RECORD_VIDEO`. For example, if the video frame rate is 30fps, the shutterSpeed must be <= 1/30. member.summary: Gets the camera's focus ring value.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.CameraHandler.SetCameraFocusRingValueAsync(DJI.WindowsSDK.IntMsg)
member.summary: Set the focal distance by simulating the focus ring adjustment. Value can have a range of [0, `GetCameraFocusRingMaxValueAsync`], which represents infinity and the closest possible focal distance. For some lenses, the minimum focus ring value is larger than 0. For example the minimum of DJI MFT 15mm f/1.7 ASPH is 270. To retrieve the minimum value, perform the following steps: (1) Call `SetCameraFocusModeAsync` with `AF`. (2) Call `SetCameraFocusTargetAsync` with the furthest target (>30m). (3) Call `GetCameraFocusRingValueAsync` to get the current focus ring value. This is the minimum value. The maximum value can be retrieved using `GetCameraFocusRingMaxValueAsync`.
member.param: A parameter object of type IntMsg.

member.name: E:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.CameraHandler.CameraFocusRingValueChanged
member.summary: Subscribe the event to receive changes of the camera's focus ring value.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.CameraHandler.GetSpotMeteringTargetPointAsync
member.summary: Gets the spot metering area row index and column index. In order to make the method work, The camera exposure mode should be `PROGRAM`, `SHUTTER_PRIORITY` or `APERTURE_PRIORITY`, the exposure metering mode must be `SPOT`, and `GetAELockEnabledAsync` must be false.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.CameraHandler.SetSpotMeteringTargetPointAsync(DJI.WindowsSDK.IntPoint2D)
member.summary: Sets the spot metering area index. The valid spots are returned from `GetExposureMeteringPointCountAsync`. The row index increases top to bottom across the image. The column increases left to right. In order to make the method work, The camera exposure mode should be `PROGRAM`, `SHUTTER_PRIORITY` or `APERTURE_PRIORITY`, the exposure metering mode must be `SPOT`, and `GetAELockEnabledAsync` must be false.
member.param: A parameter object of type IntPoint2D.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.CameraHandler.StartShootPhotoAsync
member.summary: Camera starts to take photo with one of the camera capture modes (shoot photo modes).Also, Precondition: 1. Camera must be in Shoot Photo mode. Some camera's may support shooting photos in Record Video mode. 2. The SD card or the internal storage state should be checked before this method is used to ensure sufficient space exists. Post condition: If the capture mode is either Burst or Interval, calling `StopShootPhotoAsync` will be required for the camera to stop taking photos.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.CameraHandler.StopShootPhotoAsync
member.summary: Camera stops taking photos. Precondition: 1. `StartShootPhotoAsync` has been invoked and the shoot mode is either Interval or Time-lapse. 2. If the shoot mode is set to `NORMAL`, the camera will automatically stop taking the photo once the individual photo is taken.

member.summary: This class contains components of the Intelligent Flight Assistant and provides methods to change its settings.

member.name: P:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.ProductIndex
member.summary: The index of the product to which this component handler belongs. The default product index is 0.

member.name: P:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.ComponentIndex
member.summary: The index of the component. It is unique for a type of components inside a product. It is useful when a product has multiple handlers of the same kind. If the product only has one handler of this kind, the index is 0.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.Finalize
member.summary: The destructor. It should not be called explicitly.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.StartAlignedPushDataAsync
member.summary: Starts the aligned push data from the flight assistant. Receives the push data from `DoublePoint3DChangedEventHandler` and `AttitudeChangedEventHandler`.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.StopAlignedPushDataAsync
member.summary: Stops the aligned push data from the flight assistant.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.GetAlignedPushDataStartedAsync
member.summary: Determines if the aligned push data is started.

member.name: E:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.AlignedPushDataStartedChanged
member.summary: Subscribe the event to receive changes about whether the aligned push data is started.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.GetAlignedAircraftLocationAsync
member.summary: Gets the aircraft location in a local coordinate (N-E-G). The origin point is the takeoff location. The aircraft's location from the flight assistant is aligned with the gimbal attitude from `GetAlignedGimbalAttitudeAsync`, which means that the flight controller will try to synchronize them based on the internal clock and pushes them to SDK at the same time. This is only valid when `GetAlignedPushDataStartedAsync` is true. Start the push data by calling `StartAlignedPushDataAsync`. CAUTION: starting the push data may consume the bandwidth. Use it only when necessary.

member.name: E:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.AlignedAircraftLocationChanged
member.summary: Subscribe the event to receive changes of the aircraft location in a local coordinate (N-E-G). The origin point is the takeoff location. The aircraft's location from the flight assistant is aligned with the gimbal attitude from `GetAlignedGimbalAttitudeAsync`, which means that the flight controller will try to synchronize them based on the internal clock and pushes them to SDK at the same time. This is only valid when `GetAlignedPushDataStartedAsync` is true. Start the push data by calling `StartAlignedPushDataAsync`. CAUTION: starting the push data may consume the bandwidth. Use it only when necessary.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.GetAlignedGimbalAttitudeAsync
member.summary: Gets the gimbal attitude aligned by the flight assistant. Different from the attitude updated by the gimbal, the gimbal attitude from the flight assistant is aligned with the location from `GetAlignedAircraftLocationAsync`, which means that the flight controller will try to synchronize them based on the internal clock and pushes them to SDK at the same time. This is only valid when `GetAlignedPushDataStartedAsync` is true. Start the push data by calling `StartAlignedPushDataAsync`. CAUTION: starting the push data may consume the bandwidth. Use it only when necessary.

member.name: E:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.AlignedGimbalAttitudeChanged
member.summary: Subscribe the event to receive changes of the gimbal attitude aligned by the flight assistant. Different from the attitude updated by the gimbal, the gimbal attitude from the flight assistant is aligned with the location from `GetAlignedAircraftLocationAsync`, which means that the flight controller will try to synchronize them based on the internal clock and pushes them to SDK at the same time. This is only valid when `GetAlignedPushDataStartedAsync` is true. Start the push data by calling `StartAlignedPushDataAsync`. CAUTION: starting the push data may consume the bandwidth. Use it only when necessary.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.GetRTHObstacleAvoidanceEnabledAsync
member.summary: Determines if Obstacle Avoidance is enabled during RTH. This is only active when the environment is bright enough. It is not active when the aircraft is landing. CAUTION: If RTH Obstacle Avoidance is disabled, aircraft will not check obstacles during RTH or ascend to avoid obstacles, which may cause great risks.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.GetPrecisionLandingEnabledAsync
member.summary: Determines if precision landing is enabled. When enabled, the aircraft will record its take-off location visually (as well as with GPS). On a Return-To- Home action the aircraft will attempt to perform a precision landing using the additional visual information. This method only works on a Return-To-Home action when the home location is successfully recorded during take-off, and not changed during flight.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.SetPrecisionLandingEnabledAsync(DJI.WindowsSDK.BoolMsg)
member.summary: Enables/disables precision landing. When enabled, the aircraft will record its take-off location visually (as well as with GPS). On a Return-To-Home action the aircraft will attempt to perform a precision landing using the additional visual information. This method only works on a Return-To-Home action when the home location is successfully recorded during take-off, and not changed during flight.
member.param: A parameter object of type BoolMsg.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightAssistantHandler.GetLandingProtectionEnabledAsync
member.summary: Determines if landing protection is enabled. During auto-landing, the downwards facing vision sensor will check if the ground surface is flat enough for a safe landing. If it is not and landing protection is enabled, then landing will abort and need to be manually performed by the user.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler
member.summary: This class contains components of the flight controller and provides methods to send different commands to the flight controller.

member.name: P:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.ProductIndex
member.summary: The index of the product to which this component handler belongs. The default product index is 0.

member.name: P:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.ComponentIndex
member.summary: The index of the component. It is unique for a type of components inside a product. It is useful when a product has multiple handlers of the same kind. If the product only has one handler of this kind, the index is 0.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.Finalize
member.summary: The destructor. It should not be called explicitly.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.StartTakeoffAsync
member.summary: Starts aircraft takeoff. Takeoff is considered complete when the aircraft is hovering 1.2 meters (4 feet) above the ground. The Task value is returned when aircraft crosses 0.5 meters (1.6 feet). If the motors are already on, this command cannot be executed.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.StopTakeoffAsync
member.summary: Stops aircraft takeoff. If called before `StartTakeoffAsync` is complete, the aircraft will cancel takeoff (`StartTakeoffAsync` task will return an error) and hover at the current height.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.StartAutoLandingAsync
member.summary: Starts auto-landing of the aircraft. The task value will return once aircraft begins to descend for auto-land.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.StopAutoLandingAsync
member.summary: Stops auto-landing of the aircraft. If called before `StartAutoLandingAsync` is complete, then the auto landing will be canceled (`StartAutoLandingAsync` task will return an error) and the aircraft will hover at its current location.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.StartCompasCalibrationAsync
member.summary: Starts compass calibration. Make sure there are no magnets or metal objects near the compass.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.StopCompassCalibrationAsync
member.summary: Stops compass calibration.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.StartGoHomeAsync
member.summary: The aircraft will start to go home. The task will return execution result once this method is invoked.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.StopGoHomeAsync
member.summary: The aircraft will stop going home and will hover in place.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.ConfirmLandingAsync
member.summary: Confirms continuation of landing action. When the clearance between the aircraft and the ground is less than 0.3m, the aircraft will pause landing and wait for user's confirmation. Can use `GetIsLandingConfirmationNeededAsync` to check if confirmation is needed. It is supported by flight controller firmware 3.2.0.0 and above.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.GetIsLandingConfirmationNeededAsync
member.summary: Determines if the clearance between the aircraft and the ground is less than 0.3m, and confirmation from the user is needed to continue the landing. When the confirmation is needed, `ConfirmLandingAsync` can be used to continue landing. It is supported by flight controller firmware 3.2.0.0 or above.

member.name: E:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.FlightControllerHandler.IsLandingConfirmationNeededChanged
member.summary: Subscribe the event to receive changes about whether confirmation from the user is needed to continue the landing. Confirmation is needed when the clearance between the aircraft and the ground is less than 0.3m, and the flight controller is not sure if it is safe to continue the landing. When the confirmation is needed, `ConfirmLandingAsync` can be used to continue landing. It is supported by flight controller firmware 3.2.0.0 or above.

member.summary: Sets the minimum altitude, relative to where the aircraft took off, at which the aircraft must be before going home. This can be useful when the user foresees obstacles in the aircraft's flight path. member.summary: Gets the maximum radius, in meters, an aircraft can fly from its home location and still make it all the way back home, based on altitude, distance, battery, etc. If the aircraft goes out farther than the max radius, it will fly as far back home as it can and land. If the aircraft is using the simulator, this value will be 0..

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.Components.RemoteControllerHandler
member.summary: This class represents the remote controller of the aircraft. It provides methods to change the settings of the physical remote controller. A remote controller is a device that can have a battery, radio, buttons, sticks, wheels, and output ports for video. The mobile device is connected to the remote controller, which is always sending out information about what everything is doing. The normal remote controller is called the master.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.DJISDKManager
member.summary: This class is the entry point for using the SDK with a DJI product. Most importantly, this class is used to register the SDK, and to connect to and access the product. This class also provides access to important feature managers. SDK Registration using must be successful before the SDK can be used with a DJI product.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.DJISDKManager.SDKRegistrationStateChangedEventHandler
member.summary: Delegate type that use to subscribe the SDK registration state and error code if there is any error.
member.param: The error code if there is any error. It is valid when the state is `Failed`.

member.summary: Subscribe the event to receive the change of SDK registration state.

member.summary: Destructor. It should not be called explicitly.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.DJISDKManager.RegisterApp(System.String)
member.summary: The first time the app is initialized after installation, the app connects to a DJI Server through the internet to verify the Application Key. The request will include the following information: - App key - Package ID - System platform, version and name - UUID generated by platform's API (`EasClientDeviceInformation.Id`) - System version Subsequent app starts will use locally cached verification information to register the app when the cached information is still valid.
member.param: The key used to register SDK for the application. This can be applied in DJI Develop Center.

member.name: P:DJI.WindowsSDK.DJISDKManager.SDKRegistrationResultCode
member.summary: Determines if SDK is registered. This is the pre-condition of using most of the features in SDK.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.CustomUnlockZone
member.summary: Users can unlock areas of a restricted fly zone through http://www.dji.com/flysafe/custom-unlock. A user needs to show special authorization (usually from a third party such as a regulatory or managing agency) as part of the process to unlock the area within the restricted fly zone. Therefore each request is unique and customized to the individual. If the request is successful, the unlocked area is tied to the user's account as an Custom Unlock Zone. This class contains the properties of an Custom Unlock Zone.

member.returns: A string value of start time.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler
member.summary: Fly Zone Handler gives information about nearby fly zones, and APIs to unlock zones that can be unlocked. Depending on location, there are three types of fly zones possible: - `Circle`: Cylinder or truncated cone volume with four levels of restriction: - Warning Zones : no restriction - Enhanced warning zones : Flight restricted, can be unlocked for flight when the user logs into their DJI account - Authorization zones : Flight restricted, can be unlocked for flight when the user logs into their DJI account and the account has been authorized to unlock authorization zones. - Restricted zones : Flight restricted - `Polygon`: Fly zone that consists of one or more sub fly zones that are cylinders or complex volumes with different height limitations. A height limitation of 0 means flight is completely restricted.

member.name: P:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.ProductIndex
member.summary: The index of the product to which this component handler belongs. The default product index is 0.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.GetFlyZonesInSurroundArea
member.summary: Gets all the fly zones within 10 km of the aircraft.
member.returns: Information of fly zones around the aircraft if the operation has no error. The information may be null when there is no fly zones around the aircraft.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.ReloadUnlockedZoneGroupsFromServer
member.summary: Reloads the unlocked zone groups unlocked by the current user's account from the server. For all products this includes both self unlocked and custom unlocked zones. Each unlocked zone group corresponds to one aircraft serial number. After launch, SDK will call this method once. It will call this method again when either the network connection or the current account state changes (e.g. when a new user successfully logs in). Call this method any other time to trigger the reloading manually. Calling this method will NOT synchronize the loaded zone groups onto the aircraft. To get a list of groups currently loaded from the server, call `GetLoadedUnlockedZoneGroups`. User will need to manually call `SyncUnlockedZoneGroupToAircraft` to synchronize the unlocked group to the connected aircraft after the unlocked zone groups are reloaded.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.GetLoadedUnlockedZoneGroups
member.summary: Gets the unlocked zone groups loaded from the server. Each zone group corresponds to one aircraft. The loaded zone groups will NOT be synchronized to the aircraft automatically. User need to manually invoke `SyncUnlockedZoneGroupToAircraft` to synchronize the unlocked zone group to the connected aircraft. Invoke `ReloadUnlockedZoneGroupsFromServer` to trigger the reloading of unlocked zone groups manually.
member.returns: Unlocked zone groups loaded from the server associated to the logged-in account. The result will be null when this is some error or there is no unlocked zone group associated to the logged-in account.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.SyncUnlockedZoneGroupToAircraft(DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.UnlockZoneGroup)
member.summary: Synchronizes the unlocked zone group to the connected aircraft. SDK will select the unlocked zone group that matches the serial number of the connected aircraft. After the unlocked zone group is synchronized to the aircraft successfully, the latest unlocked fly zones and the custom unlock zones on the aircraft can be checked by the follow methods: - Unlocked fly zones: `GetUnlockedFlyZonesForAircraft` - Custom unlock zones: `GetCustomUnlockZonesFromAircraft`

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.GetUnlockedFlyZonesForAircraft
member.summary: Gets a list of authorization fly zones unlocked by the account for the connected aircraft. It includes fly zones unlocked by the Flight Planner (http://www.dji.com/flysafe/geo-system#planner), and the ones unlocked during flight using DJI Go or any DJI Mobile/Windows SDK based application. This list does NOT include fly zones unlocked by custom unlocking.
member.returns: Information of unlocked fly zones on the aircraft if the operation has no error. The information may be null when there is no unlocked fly zones on the aircraft.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.UnlockFlyZones(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.UInt32})
member.summary: Unlocks the selected fly zones. This method can be used to unlock authorization zones. After unlocking the zones, flight will be unrestricted in those zones until the unlock expires. The unlocking record will be linked to the user's account and will be accessible to DJI Go and other DJI Mobile/Windows SDK based applications. Data Protection Notes - Calling this method will send the following protected data to DJI server: - User account information - The serial number of the connected aircraft.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.SetUnlockingEnabled(DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneInformation,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set the enabled state to the selected authorization fly zone on the aircraft. This method can be used to set the enabled state for specific authorization fly zone currently on the aircraft. All authorization fly zones on the aircraft can be retrieved with `GetUnlockedFlyZonesForAircraft`.
member.param: The fly zone of to enabled.
The enabled state set to the authorization fly zone on the aircraft.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.GetUnlockingEnabled(DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneInformation)
member.summary: Get the enabled state of the selected authorization fly zone on the aircraft. All authorization fly zones on the aircraft can be retrieved with `GetUnlockedFlyZonesForAircraft`.
member.param: Get the enabled state of the selected authorization fly zone on the aircraft.
member.returns: The enabled state of the selected authorization fly zone on the aircraft. If the selected authorization fly zone could not be found on the aircraft, an unknown error code of the operation will be returned.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.GetCustomUnlockZonesFromAircraft
member.summary: Gets the Custom Unlock Zones currently on the aircraft.
member.returns: Customs unlock zones on the aircraft. The result will be null when there is some error or there is no custom unlock zones on the aircraft.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.DisableCustomUnlockZone
member.summary: Disables the custom unlock zone currently on the aircraft if there is. The currently enabled custom unlock zone can be retrieved with `GetEnabledCustomUnlockZone`.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.EnableCustomUnlockZone(DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.CustomUnlockZone)
member.summary: Enables an Custom Unlock Zones that is on the aircraft. All Custom Unlock Zones on the aircraft can be retrieved with `GetCustomUnlockZonesFromAircraft`. At any time, only one Custom Unlock Zone can be enabled. Enabling an Custom Unlock Zone will disable the previously enabled zone.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.FlySafe.FlyZoneHandler.GetEnabledCustomUnlockZone
member.returns: The currently enabled custom unlock zone on the aircraft. The result will be null when this is some error or there is no enabled custom unlock zone on the aircraft.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler
member.summary: `WaypointMissionHandler` can be used to run and monitor Waypoint Missions. It can be accessed from `WaypointMissionManager`.

member.name: P:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.ProductIndex
member.summary: The index of the product to which this component handler belongs. The default product index is 0.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.LoadMission(DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission)
member.summary: Loads a waypoint mission into the device memory. A mission can be loaded only when the WaypointMissionState is one of the following:`READY_TO_UPLOAD` or `READY_TO_EXECUTE`. Calling LoadMission when the current state is READY_TO_EXECUTE will change the state to `READY_TO_UPLOAD`.
member.returns: The operation error code. When mission data is invalid or the mission cannot be loaded in the current state, the value is `PARAMETERS_SET_ERROR` or `INVALID_REQUEST_IN_CURRENT_STATE`.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.UploadMission
member.summary: Starts to upload the GetLoadedMission to the aircraft. It can only be called when the `GetCurrentState` is `READY_TO_UPLOAD`. If a timeout error occurs during the previous upload, the upload operation will resume from the previous break-point. After a mission is uploaded successfully, the `GetCurrentState` will become `READY_TO_EXECUTE`.The upload progress will be notify by `UploadStateChangedEventHandler` .

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.RetryUploadMission
member.summary: Retry upload waypoint mission.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.CancelUploadMission
member.summary: Cancel upload mission . It can only be called when the `GetCurrentState` is `UPLOADING`

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.DownloadMission
member.summary: If app is restart and waypoint mission is executing,you need to download mission from aircraft. The operation will download information of each waypoint from aircraft and save it to `GetLoadedMission`. If a download operation is started, the manager will download the information of waypoints missing in `GetLoadedMission` one-by-one in ascending order. It can only be called when the `GetCurrentState` is one of the following: - `EXECUTING` - `EXECUTE_PAUSED`,The download progress will be notify by `DownloadStateChangedEventHandler` .

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.RetryDownloadMission
member.summary: Retry downdownload waypoint mission.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.CancelDownloadMission
member.summary: Cancel download mission.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.StartMission
member.summary: Starts the execution of the uploaded mission. It can only be called when the `GetCurrentState` is `READY_TO_EXECUTE`. After a mission is started successfully, the `GetCurrentState` will become `EXECUTING`.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.StopMission
member.summary: Stops the executing or paused mission. It can only be called when the `GetCurrentState` is one of the following: - `EXECUTING` - `EXECUTE_PAUSED` After a mission is stopped successfully, `GetCurrentState` will become `READY_TO_UPLOAD`.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.PauseMission
member.summary: Pauses the executing mission. It can only be called when the `WaypointMissionState` is `EXECUTING`. After a mission is paused successfully, the `GetCurrentState` will become `EXECUTE_PAUSED`.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.ResumeMission
member.summary: Resumes the paused mission. It can only be called when the `GetCurrentState` is `EXECUTE_PAUSED`. After a mission is resumed successfully, the `GetCurrentState` will become `EXECUTING`.

member.name: E:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.StateChanged
member.summary: Receive the event related to current state change.See `StateChangedEventHandler`

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.GetCurrentState
member.summary: The current state of the manager.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.Mission.Waypoint.WaypointMissionHandler.GetLoadedMission
member.summary: Gets the currently loaded mission of the manager. There are two ways to load a mission. 1. A mission can be loaded by user through loadMission. 2. If the aircraft is already executing a waypoint mission when SDK is re-connected, the manager will download part of the mission's information from the aircraft and load it automatically. In that case, the loaded mission will only contain the summary of the executing mission but information for each waypoint is absent. User can call DownloadMission to get all the information for the loaded mission. The loadedMission will be reset to null when the execution of the loadedMission is stopped, finished or interrupted.

member.name: M:DJI.WindowsSDK.UserAccount.UserAccountManager.CreateLoginView(System.Boolean)
member.summary: After invoking this method, a webview redirecting users to log into their DJI account will be created. The life cycle and the visibility of the webview is controlled by the developer. For end users outside of China, authorization is required to unlock authorization zones. After the login process, if `authorizationRequired` is YES, and the user is currently out of China and the account has not been authorized to unlock authorization zones, the webview will then redirect users to authorize their account.
member.param: If authorization is needed. If so, the view will jump to the authorization page after login.
member.returns: A webview that contains the login page.

member.summary: Logs out the DJI user that is logged in.
member.returns: A `Task` that returns the logout result asynchronously.

member.summary: In this mode, the user can download media to the Mobile Device.

member.summary: In this mode, live stream resolution and frame rate will be 1080i50 (PAL) or 720p60 (NTSC). In this mode videos can be recorded. member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointActionType
member.summary: Waypoint action types.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointActionType.STAY
member.summary: Keeps the aircraft at the waypoint's location. The `actionParam` parameter will determine how much time in milliseconds the aircraft will stay at the location with range of [0, 32767] milliseconds.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointActionType.START_TAKE_PHOTO
member.summary: Starts to shoot a photo. The `actionParam` for the waypoint action will be ignored. The maximum time set to execute this waypoint action is 6 seconds. If the time while executing the waypoint action goes above 6 seconds, the aircraft will stop executing the waypoint action and will move on to the next waypoint action, if one exists.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointActionType.START_RECORD
member.summary: Starts recording. The `actionParam` for the waypoint action will be ignored. The maximum time set to execute this waypoint action is 6 seconds. If the time while executing the waypoint action goes above 6 seconds (e.g. the camera is not present) the aircraft will stop executing the waypoint action and will move on to the next waypoint action, if one exists.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointActionType.STOP_RECORD
member.summary: Stops recording. The `actionParam` for the waypoint action will be ignored. The maximum time set to execute this waypoint action is 6 seconds. If the time while executing the waypoint action goes above 6 seconds (e.g. the camera is not present) the aircraft will stop executing the waypoint action and will move on to the next waypoint action, if one exists.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointActionType.ROTATE_AIRCRAFT
member.summary: Rotates the aircraft's yaw. The rotation direction is determined by the waypoint's `turnMode` property. The `actionParam` value must be in the range of [-180, 180] degrees.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointActionType.GIMBAL_PITCH
member.summary: Rotates the gimbal's pitch. The `actionParam` value should be in range [-90, 0] degrees.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointActionType.UNKNOWN
member.summary: Unknown.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointTurnMode
member.summary: How the aircraft will turn at a waypoint to transition between headings.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointTurnMode.CLOCKWISE
member.summary: Changes the heading of the aircraft by rotating the aircraft clockwise.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointTurnMode.COUNTER_CLOCKWISE
member.summary: Changes the heading of the aircraft by rotating the aircraft anti-clockwise.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointTurnMode.UNKNOWN
member.summary: Unknown.

member.summary: Actions taken when the waypoint mission has finished.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionFinishedAction.NO_ACTION
member.summary: No further action will be taken on completion of mission. At this point, the aircraft can be controlled by the remote controller.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionFinishedAction.GO_HOME
member.summary: The aircraft will go home when the mission is complete. If the aircraft is more than 20m away from the home point it will go home and land. Otherwise, it will land directly at the current location.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionFinishedAction.AUTO_LAND
member.summary: The aircraft will land automatically at the last waypoint.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionFinishedAction.GO_FIRST_WAYPOINT
member.summary: The aircraft will go back to its first waypoint and hover in position.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionFinishedAction.CONTINUE_UNTIL_END
member.summary: When the aircraft reaches its final waypoint, it will hover without ending the mission. The joystick can still be used to pull the aircraft back along its previous waypoints. The only way this mission can end is if stopMission is called.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionFinishedAction.UNKNOWN
member.summary: Unknown.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionHeadingMode
member.summary: Current waypoint mission heading mode.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionHeadingMode.AUTO
member.summary: Aircraft's heading will always be in the direction of flight.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionHeadingMode.USING_INITIAL_DIRECTION
member.summary: Aircraft's heading will be set to the heading when reaching the first waypoint. Before reaching the first waypoint, the aircraft's heading can be controlled by the remote controller. When the aircraft reaches the first waypoint, its heading will be fixed.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionHeadingMode.CONTROL_BY_REMOTE_CONTROLLER
member.summary: Aircraft's heading will be controlled by the remote controller.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionHeadingMode.USING_WAYPOINT_HEADING
member.summary: Aircraft's heading will be gradually set to the next waypoint heading while travelling between two adjacent waypoints.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionHeadingMode.TOWARD_POINT_OF_INTEREST
member.summary: Aircraft's heading will always toward point of interest.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionHeadingMode.UNKNOWN
member.summary: Unknown.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionFlightPathMode
member.summary: Waypoint mission flight path mode.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionFlightPathMode.NORMAL
member.summary: The flight path will be normal and the aircraft will move from one waypoint to the next in straight lines.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionFlightPathMode.CURVED
member.summary: The flight path will be curved and the aircraft will move from one waypoint to the next in a curved motion, adhering to the `cornerRadiusInMeters`, which is set in `Waypoint`.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionFlightPathMode.UNKNOWN
member.summary: Unknown.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionGotoFirstWaypointMode
member.summary: This enum will determine the goto point mode while the drone executes the flight.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionGotoFirstWaypointMode.SAFELY
member.summary: Go to the waypoint safely. The aircraft will rise to the same altitude of the waypoint if the current altitude is lower then the waypoint altitude. It then goes to the waypoint coordinate from the current altitude, and proceeds to the altitude of the waypoint.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionGotoFirstWaypointMode.POINT_TO_POINT
member.summary: Go to the waypoint from the current aircraft point to the waypoint directly.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionGotoFirstWaypointMode.UNKNOWN
member.summary: Unknown.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionState
member.summary: All the possible state of waypoint mission handler.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionState.DISCONNECTED
member.summary: The connection between the mobile device, remote controller and aircraft is broken.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionState.RECOVERING
member.summary: The connection between the mobile device, remote controller and aircraft is built-up. The operator is synchronizing the state from the aircraft.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionState.NOT_SUPPORTED
member.summary: The connected product does not support waypoint mission.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionState.READY_TO_UPLOAD
member.summary: The aircraft is ready to upload a mission.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionState.UPLOADING
member.summary: The uploading is started successfully. Detail information for each waypoint is being uploaded one by one.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionState.READY_TO_EXECUTE
member.summary: Waypoint mission is uploaded completely and the aircraft is ready to start the execution.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionState.EXECUTING
member.summary: The execution is started successfully.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionState.EXECUTE_PAUSED
member.summary: Waypoint mission is paused successfully. User can call resume mission to continue the execution.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionState.UNKNOWN
member.summary: The state of the operator is unknown. It is the initial state when the handler is just created.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionExecuteState
member.summary: Current waypoint mission state.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionExecuteState.INITIALIZING
member.summary: Waypoint mission is initializing, which means the mission has started and the aircraft is going to the first waypoint.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionExecuteState.MOVING
member.summary: Aircraft is currently moving toward the mission's next waypoint. This happens when the `flightPathMode` is set to `NORMAL`.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionExecuteState.CURVE_MODE_MOVING
member.summary: Aircraft is currently moving. This happens when the `flightPathMode` is set to `CURVED`.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionExecuteState.CURVE_MODE_TURNING
member.summary: Aircraft is currently turning. This happens when the `flightPathMode` is set to `CURVED`.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionExecuteState.BEGIN_ACTION
member.summary: Aircraft has reached a waypoint, has rotated to the new heading and is now processing actions. This state will be called before the waypoint actions starts executing and will occur for each waypoint action.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionExecuteState.DOING_ACTION
member.summary: Aircraft is at a waypoint and is executing an action.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionExecuteState.FINISHED_ACTION
member.summary: Aircraft is at a waypoint and has finished executing the current waypoint action. This state occurs once for each waypoint action.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionExecuteState.RETURN_TO_FIRST_POINT
member.summary: Aircraft has returned to the first waypoint. This happens when the `finishedAction` is set to `GO_FIRST_WAYPOINT`.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionExecuteState.PAUSED
member.summary: The mission is currently paused by the user.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMissionExecuteState.UNKNOWN
member.summary: Unknown.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.FCGPSSignalLevel
member.summary: GPS signal levels, which are used to measure the signal quality.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.FCGPSSignalLevel.LEVEL_0
member.summary: The GPS has almost no signal, which is very bad.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.FCGPSSignalLevel.LEVEL_1
member.summary: The GPS signal is very weak.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.FCGPSSignalLevel.LEVEL_2
member.summary: The GPS signal is weak. At this level, the aircraft's go home functionality will still work.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.FCGPSSignalLevel.LEVEL_3
member.summary: The GPS signal is good. At this level, the aircraft can hover in the air.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.FCGPSSignalLevel.LEVEL_4
member.summary: The GPS signal is very good. At this level, the aircraft can record the home point.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.FCGPSSignalLevel.LEVEL_5
member.summary: The GPS signal is very strong.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.FCGPSSignalLevel.LEVEL_None
member.summary: There is no GPS signal.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.FCGPSSignalLevel.UNKNOWN
member.summary: Unknown.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.RCFlightModeSwitch
member.summary: Remote Controller Flight Mode switch position.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.RCFlightModeSwitch.SWITCH_ONE
member.summary: Position One. For all products except Mavic Pro, this is the left most position of the flight mode switch on a remote controller from the perspective of the pilot. For example, on a Phantom 4 remote controller, Position One is labeled "A". For Mavic Pro, Spark and Mavic Air, this is the position that is furthest away from the pilot and labeled "Sport".

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.RCFlightModeSwitch.SWITCH_TWO
member.summary: Position Two. For all products except Mavic Pro, this is the middle position of the flight mode switch on a remote controller from the perspective of the pilot. For example, on a Phantom 4 remote controller, Position Two is labeled "S". For Mavic Pro, Spark and Mavic Air, this is the position that is closest to the pilot (the P position).

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.RCFlightModeSwitch.SWITCH_THREE
member.summary: Position Three. For all products except Mavic Pro, this is the right most position of the flight mode switch on a remote controller from the perspective of the pilot. For example, on a Phantom 4 remote controller, Position Two is labeled "P". Mavic Pro, Spark or Mavic Air does not have a third position for the flight mode switch.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.RCFlightModeSwitch.UNKNOWN
member.summary: Unknown.

member.summary: true to ignore the roll value of this rotation so that the gimbal will not rotate roll.

member.summary: true to ignore the yaw value of this rotation so that the gimbal will not rotate yaw.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.PhotoIntervalShootSettings.count
member.summary: The number of photos to capture. The value range is [2, 255]. If 255 is selected, then the camera will continue to take pictures until `StopShootPhotoAsync` is called. For thermal imaging camera and Z30 camera, it can only be set to 255.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.PhotoIntervalShootSettings.interval
member.summary: The time interval between when two photos are taken. The range for this parameter depends the photo file format(`PhotoStorageFormat`). When the file format is JPEG, the range is [2, 2^16 - 1] seconds; when the file format is RAW or RAW+JPEG, the range is [10, 2^16 - 1] seconds.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint
member.summary: The class represents a target point in the waypoint mission. For a waypoint mission, a flight route consists of multiple `Waypoint` objects. The user can also define the actions to perform for each `Waypoint`.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.location
member.summary: Waypoint latitude and longitude in degrees.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.altitude
member.summary: Altitude of the aircraft in meters when it reaches waypoint. The altitude of the aircraft is relative to the ground at the take-off location, has a range of [-200,500], and should not be larger than the aircraft's maximum altitude. If two adjacent waypoints have different altitudes, the altitude will gradually change as the aircraft flies between waypoints.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.turnMode
member.summary: Determines whether the aircraft will turn clockwise or anticlockwise when changing its heading.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.heading
member.summary: The heading to which the aircraft will rotate by the time it reaches the waypoint. The aircraft heading will gradually change between two waypoints with different headings if the waypoint mission's headingMode is set to `USING_WAYPOINT_HEADING`. A heading has a range of [-180, 180] degrees, where 0 represents True North.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.gimbalPitch
member.summary: Gimbal pitch angle when reached this waypoint. This property is used when the `WaypointMission` property `gimbalPitchRotationEnabled` is true. Value should in range [-90, 0] degree.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.actionRepeatTimes
member.summary: Determines how many times the set of waypoint actions are repeated. The default value is one time, and the maximum is 15.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.actionTimeoutInSeconds
member.summary: The maximum time set to execute all the waypoint actions for a waypoint. If the time while executing the waypoint actions goes above the time set, the aircraft will stop executing the waypoint actions for the current waypoint and will move on to the next waypoint. The value of this property must be in the range of [0, 999] seconds. The default value is 60 seconds.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.cornerRadiusInMeters
member.summary: Corner radius of the waypoint. When the flight path mode is `CURVED` the flight path near a waypoint will be a curve (rounded corner) with radius [0.2,1000]. When there is a corner radius, the aircraft will never go through the waypoint. By default, the radius is 0.2 m. If the corner is made of three adjacent waypoints (Short for A, B, C). Then the radius of A(short for Ra) plus radius of B(short for Rb) must be smaller than the distance between A and B. The radius of the first and the last waypoint in a mission does not affect the flight path and it should keep the default value (0.2m).

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.speed
member.summary: The base automatic speed of the aircraft as it moves between this waypoint and the next waypoint with range [0, 15] m/s. By default, it is 0.0 and the aircraft will fly with `autoFlightSpeed` of the waypoint mission. If greater than 0, 'speed' will override `autoFlightSpeed`. This 'speed' can only define movement forward through the waypoint mission in comparison to `autoFlightSpeed` which can be both forward and backwards through a waypoint mission. Waypoint mission speed priority from highest to lowest is: 1) manual speed adjustment with remote controller joy sticks 2) 'speed' 3) The updated auto flight speed during the mission 4) `autoFlightSpeed` Warning: 'speed', `shootPhotoTimeInterval` and `shootPhotoDistanceInterval` relate to behavior between this waypoint and the next waypoint in the mission. In comparison, turnMode, altitude and heading relate to behavior between the last waypoint and this waypoint in the waypoint mission. Only supported by flight controller firmware 3.2.10.0 or above.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.shootPhotoTimeInterval
member.summary: The time interval in seconds when two photos are taken as the aircraft moves between the current waypoint and the next waypoint. The first photo will be taken as the aircraft leaves the current waypoint. The maximum value is 6,000.0. The minimum value is above 0.0 and depends on the camera type and the camera parameters. When the photo file format is JPEG, the recommended minimum value is 2.0. When the photo file format is RAW, the minimum value is 10.0. If the input exceeds the camera's capability, the pictures will be taken at the maximum possible speed. The default value is 0.0 and no photo will be taken. For a waypoint, either shootPhotoTimeInterval or shootPhotoDistanceInterval is 0.0. Input with precision of greater than 1 decimal places, will be rounded to 1. Warning: 'speed', `shootPhotoTimeInterval` and `shootPhotoDistanceInterval` relate to behavior between this waypoint and the next waypoint in the mission. In comparison, turnMode, altitude and heading relate to behavior between the last waypoint and this waypoint in the waypoint mission. Only supported by flight controller firmware 3.2.10.0 or above.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.shootPhotoDistanceInterval
member.summary: The distance interval in meters when two photos are taken as the aircraft moves between the current waypoint and the next waypoint. The maximum value is 6,000.0. The minimum value is above 0.0 and depends on the camera type, the camera parameters and the flight speed. When the photo file format is JPEG, the time interval between two photos cannot smaller than 2 seconds. When the photo file format is RAW, the time interval between two photos cannot smaller than 10 seconds. If the input exceeds the camera's capability, the taken photos may be less than expectation. The default value is 0.0 and no photo will be taken. For a waypoint, either `shootPhotoTimeInterval` or `shootPhotoDistanceInterval` is 0.0. Input with precision of greater than 1 decimal places, will be rounded to 1. Warning: 'speed', `shootPhotoTimeInterval` and `shootPhotoDistanceInterval` relate to behavior between this waypoint and the next waypoint in the mission. In comparison, turnMode, altitude and heading relate to behavior between the last waypoint and this waypoint in the waypoint mission. Only supported by flight controller firmware 3.2.10.0 or above.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.Waypoint.waypointActions
member.summary: Array of all waypoint actions for the respective waypoint. The waypoint actions will be executed consecutively from the start of the array once the aircraft reaches the waypoint.

member.name: T:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission
member.summary: In the waypoint mission, the aircraft will travel between waypoints, execute actions at waypoints, and adjust heading and altitude between waypoints. Waypoints are physical locations to which the aircraft will fly. Creating a series of waypoints, in effect, will program a flight route for the aircraft to follow. Actions can also be added to waypoints, which will be carried out when the aircraft reaches the waypoint. The aircraft travels between waypoints automatically at a base speed. However, the user can change the speed by using the pitch joystick. If the stick is pushed up, the speed will increase. If the stick is pushed down, the speed will slow down. The stick can be pushed down to stop the aircraft and further pushed to start making the aircraft travel back along the path it came. When the aircraft is travelling through waypoints in the reverse order, it will not execute waypoint actions at each waypoint. If the stick is released, the aircraft will again travel through the waypoints in the original order, and continue to execute waypoint actions (even if executed previously). If the aircraft is pulled back along the waypoint mission all the way to the first waypoint, then it will hover in place until the stick is released enough for it to again progress through the mission from start to finish.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission.waypointCount
member.summary: Number of waypoints in the waypoint mission. Note there are some cases when the waypoint count will be different to the waypoint array length from `waypoints`. This is usually the case when the waypoint mission is still being downloaded from the aircraft and the mission object hasn't existed previously (e.g. when the mobile device is connected to an aircraft with a previously uploaded mission). In these cases, isComplete will return null.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission.maxFlightSpeed
member.summary: While the aircraft is travelling between waypoints, you can offset its speed by using the throttle joystick on the remote controller. `maxFlightSpeed` is this offset when the joystick is pushed to maximum deflection. For example, If `maxFlightSpeed` is 10 m/s, then pushing the throttle joystick all the way up will add 10 m/s to the aircraft speed, while pushing down will subtract 10 m/s from the aircraft speed. If the remote controller stick is not at maximum deflection, then the offset speed will be interpolated between [0, `maxFlightSpeed`] with a resolution of 1000 steps. If the offset speed is negative, then the aircraft will fly backwards to previous waypoints. When it reaches the first waypoint, it will then hover in place until a positive speed is applied. `maxFlightSpeed` has a range of [2,15] m/s.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission.autoFlightSpeed
member.summary: The base automatic speed of the aircraft as it moves between waypoints with range [-15, 15] m/s. The aircraft's actual speed is a combination of the base automatic speed, and the speed control given by the throttle joystick on the remote controller. If `autoFlightSpeed` > 0: Actual speed is `autoFlightSpeed` + Joystick Speed (with combined max of `maxFlightSpeed`) If autoFlightSpeed = 0: Actual speed is controlled only by the remote controller joystick. If `autoFlightSpeed` < 0 and the aircraft is at the first waypoint, the aircraft will hover in place until the speed is made positive by the remote controller joystick.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission.finishedAction
member.summary: Action the aircraft will take when the waypoint mission is complete.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission.headingMode
member.summary: Heading of the aircraft as it moves between waypoints. Default is `AUTO`.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission.flightPathMode
member.summary: The path the aircraft follows between waypoints. The aircraft can either fly directly between waypoints in a straight line, or turn near a waypoint in the curve where the waypoint location defines a part of the curve.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission.gotoFirstWaypointMode
member.summary: Defines how the aircraft will go to the first waypoint from its current position. Default is `SAFELY`.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission.exitMissionOnRCSignalLostEnabled
member.summary: Determines whether the mission should stop when connection between the aircraft and remote controller is lost. Default is `FALSE`.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission.pointOfInterest
member.summary: Aircraft heading will be fixed to the point of interest location during the waypoint mission. Used when `headingMode` is `TOWARD_POINT_OF_INTEREST`.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission.gimbalPitchRotationEnabled
member.summary: `TRUE` if the gimbal pitch rotation can be controlled during the waypoint mission. When `TRUE`, `gimbalPitch` in `Waypoint` is used to control gimbal pitch.

member.name: F:DJI.WindowsSDK.WaypointMission.repeatTimes
member.summary: Mission execution can be repeated more than once. A value of 0 means the mission only executes once, and does not repeat. A value of 1 means the mission will execute a total of two times.
